newsitem.title: USA: CME live cattle calls mixed, feeders steady to off.
newsitem.headline: CME live cattle calls mixed, feeders steady to off.

text.p: Early calls on CME live cattle futures ranged from 0.100 cent per lb lower to 0.100 higher while feeder cattle were called steady to 0.100 cent lower, livestock analysts said.
Further fund rolling, selling of June and buying of August, was expected to make for mixed price action. The "Goldman roll" started Wednesday and should continue another couple of days, traders said.
Apparent topping in wholesale beef prices is also expected to weigh on sentiment and offset recent strength in the cash cattle market, they said.
Retailer beef demand for Memorial Day is near an end which will likely lead to topping action in cash cattle, they said.

The market is also expected to start looking ahead to next week's USDA Cattle on Feed report. Placements of cattle on feed in April was well above a year ago and total on feed supplies are much larger, several analysts said.
Analysts' feedlot placement estimates for April were running as high as 127.5 percent of a year ago and on-feed estimates as high as 111 percent.

Feeder cattle futures were also expected to show a somewhat easier tone. Feeders look overbought, especially with fed cattle expected to be nearing a near-term top. This should reduce demand for replacement feeders, they said.
Profit margins at feedyards do not look as good going into late summer as they previously had. Expectations for higher corn futures should also weigh on the market, they said.
The latest CME feeder cattle index rose $0.04 to $73.24 per cwt.
